item1_summary:
Google revenues generated from advertising, other sources ("Google subscriptions, platforms, and devices"), Google Cloud, and Other Bets have been, and may continue to be, affected by other factors unique to each set of revenues . Google advertising revenues are comprised of the following: Google Search & other, Google Search and other, and Google Cloud .
 We use certain metrics to track how well traffic across various properties is monetized as it relates to our advertising revenues . Paid clicks represent engagement by users and include clicks on advertisements by end-users on Google search properties . Cost-per-click is defined as click-driven revenues divided by our total number of paid clicks . Impressions include impressions displayed to users on Google Network properties .
 Google subscriptions, platforms, and devices revenues are comprised of the following:consumer subscriptions, Google Play sales of apps and in-app purchases . Google Cloud revenues are . comprised of . revenues from YouTube services, such as YouTube TV, YouTube Music and Premium, and NFL Sunday Ticket, as well as Google One . Google also generates consumption-based fees and subscriptions .
 Google Cloud revenues have been, and may continue to be, affected by factors in addition to factors such as changes in customer usage and demand . Revenues from Other Bets are generated primarily from the sale of healthcare-related services, and internet services . Costs and expenses are generally less variable in nature and may not correlate to changes in revenue .
 Other cost of revenues primarily includes: payments to content providers from whom we license video and other content for distribution, primarily related to YouTube . TAC as a percentage of revenues generated from ads placed on Google Network properties are significantly higher than TAC . Most of the advertiser revenues from ads served on Google . properties are paid as TAC to our Google Network partners .
 The main components of our general and administrative expenses are: employee compensation expenses for employees in finance, human resources, information technology, legal, and other administrative support functions . Other expenses include expenses relating to legal and other matters, including certain fines and settlements . Other income (expense), net primarily consists of interest income, the effect of foreign currency exchange gains (losses) and impairment on our marketable and non-marketable securities, performance fees, and income (loss)
 The following table summarizes our consolidated financial results (in millions, except for per share information and percentages) See "Use of Non-GAAP Constant Currency Information" below for details relating to our use of constant currency information . For additional information on the calculation of diluted EPS, see Note 12 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item 8 of this Annual Report .
 The overall increase in employee compensation expenses was partially offset by a reduction in employee severance and related charges . Dividend payments to stockholders of Class A, Class B, and Class C shares, which were first paid in June 2024, were $7.4 billion for the year ended December 31, 2024 .
 Revenues increased $23.1 billion from 2023 to 2024 . YouTube ads revenues increased $4.6 billion . Google Network revenues decreased $953 million . Google network revenues were adversely affected by changes in foreign currency exchange rates . Google has 83,323 employees. The company also has 1,648  employees.
 Google subscriptions, platforms, and devices revenues increased $5.7 billion from 2023 to 2024 . The growth was primarily driven by an increase in subscription revenues, largely from growth in the number of paid subscribers for YouTube services followed by Google One . The following table presents revenues by geography as a percentage of revenues, determined based on the addresses of our customers .
 The effect of currency exchange rates on our business is an important factor in understanding period-to-period comparisons . We define constant currency revenues as revenues excluding the effect of foreign currency exchange rate movements as well as hedging activities . The presentation of results on a constant currency basis helps improve the ability to understand our performance .
 The results should be considered in addition to, not as a substitute for, results reported in accordance with GAAP . Results on a constant currency basis, as we present them, may not be comparable to similarly titled measures used by other companies . The following table presents the foreign currency exchange effect on international revenues and total revenues (in millions, except percentages)
 The TAC rate decreased from 21.4% to 20.7% from 2023 to 2024 primarily due to a revenue mix shift from Google Network properties to Google Search & other properties . Cost of revenues increased $13.0 billion to 2024 due to an increase in other cost of revenues and TAC .
 R&D expenses increased  $3.9 billion from 2023 to 2024, primarily driven by increases in employee compensation expenses of $1.5 billion . Sales and marketing expenses decreased $109 million, due to a combination of factors, none of which were individually significant . General and administrative expenses decreased  $2.2 billion, mainly driven by a reduction in charges related to legal and other matters .
 Certain costs are not allocated to our segments because they represent Alphabet-level activities . For further details on our segments, see Part I, Item 1 Business and Note 15 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K. gment results as Google Services, Google Cloud, and Other Bets .
 The increase in operating loss was primarily due to an increase in expenses, largely driven by employee compensation expenses in addition to a combination of factors, none of which were individually significant . OI&E, net increased $6.0 billion from 2023 to 2024 due to net gains on equity securities and a decrease in net losses on foreign currency exchange .
 The effective tax rate increased from 2023 to 2024 . The OECD is coordinating negotiations among more than 140 countries with the goal of achieving consensus around substantial changes to international tax policies . As of December 31, 2024, we had $95.7 billion in cash, cash equivalents, and short-term marketababab .
 Our principal sources of liquidity are cash, cash equivalents, and marketable securities . The primary use of capital continues to be to invest for the long-term growth of the business . We regularly evaluate our cash and capital structure, including the size, pace, and form of capital return to stockholders . The following table presents our cash flows (in millions)
 The Alphabet Inc. tivities increased from 2023 to 2024 due to an increase in cash received from customers . The increase in purchases of property and equipment is primarily driven by investments in technical infrastructure . We expect existuring cash, cash equivalents, short-term marketable securities, and cash flows from operations and financing activities to continue to be sufficient to fund our operating activities and cash c .
 The company made $32.3 billion and $52.5 billion on capital expenditures in the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2024, respectively . The company expects to increase its capital expenditures to support the growth of its AI products and services in the coming years . It also expects to continue to invest in its technical infrastructure, including servers, network equipment, and data centers, to support its long-term initiatives .
 For the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2024, our depreciation on property and equipment was $11.9 billion and $15.3 billion, respectively . As of December 31, 2024, we have entered into leases that have not yet commenced with future short-term and long-term lease payments of $773 million and $6.5 billion .
 As of December 31, 2024, we had $10.0 billion of revolving credit facilities,  $4.0billion expiring in April 2025 and $6.0bn expiring  in April 2028 . As of  January 2424, we  had senior unsecured notes outstanding with a total carrying value of $11.9 billion .
 The company intends to pay quarterly cash dividends in the future, subject to review and approval by the company’s Board of Directors in its sole discretion . The European Commission (EC) announced decisions that certain actions taken by Google infringed European competition law and imposed fines of €2.4 billion ($5.1 billion) and €1.5 billion ($1.7 billion) respectively .
 In September 2024, the EU's General Court overturned the 2019 decision and annulled the €1.5 billion fine . The EC has appealed the General Court's decision to the European Court of Justice . We included the outstanding EC fines, including any under appeal, in accrued expenses and other current liabilities on our Consolidated Balance Sheets .
 In addition, we regularly enter into multi-year, non-cancellable agreements to purchase renewable energy and energy attributes, such as renewable energy certificates . Our critical accounting estimates are those estimates that involve a significant level of uncertainty at the time the estimate was made, and changes in them have had or are reasonably likely to have a material effect on our financial condition or results of operations .
 Non-marketable equity securities are also evaluated for impairment, based on qualitative factors including the companies' financial and liquidity position and access to capital resources . When the quantitative remeasurements of fair value indicate an impairment exists, we write down the investment to its current fair value . We also have compensation arrangements with payouts based on realized returns from certain investments .
 Significant judgment is required in evaluating our uncertain tax positions and determining our provision for income taxes . No assurance can be given that the final tax outcome of these matters will not be different . We are subject to income taxes in the U.S. and foreign jurisdictions, including the IRS and other tax authorities which may assert assessments against us .
 Certain of these matters include speculative claims for substantial or indeterminate amounts of damages . We record a liability when we believe that it is probable that a loss has been incurred and the amount can be reasonably estimated . We disclose the possible loss in Note 10 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K .
 We enter into derivative instruments to hedge foreign currency risk . Principal currencies hedged included the Australian dollar, British pound, Canadian dollar, Euro, and Japanese yen . We use foreign currency forward and option contracts to offset the foreign exchange risk on monetary assets and liabilities denominated in currencies other than the functional currency of the subsidiary .
 When the U.S. dollar weakens, losses from foreign currency forward and option contracts offset the foreign currency gains related to our earnings . We designate these contracts as cash flow hedges for accounting purposes . We reflect the gains and losses of foreign currency spot rate changes as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income (AOCI)
 Our investments in both fixed rate and floating rate interest earning securities carry a degree of interest rate risk . Fixed rate securities may have their fair market value adversely affected due to a rise in interest rates . We use value-at-risk (VaR) analysis to determine the potential effect of fluctuations in interest rate fluctuations on the value of our investment portfolio .
 The portfolio is subject to a wide variety of market-related risks that could substantially reduce or increase the fair value of our holdings . Actual future gains and losses may differ from sensitivity analyses performed as of December 31, 2023 and 2024 due to the inherent limitations associated with predicting the timing and amount of changes in interest rates and our actual exposures and positions .
 The fair value measured at the time of the observable transaction is not necessarily an indication of the current fair value as of the balance sheet date . Valuations of our equity investments in private companies are inherently more complex due to the lack of readily available market data . The success of our investment in any private company is typically dependent on the likelihood of our ability to realize appreciation in the value of investments .
 Alphabet Inc. (the Company) audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of December 31, 2023 and 2024, the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, stockholders' equity and cash flows . In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of the Company at December  31,  and the results of its operations and its cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2024 .
 These financial statements are the responsibility of the Company's management . Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company’s financial statements based on our audits . We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States) (PCAOB) We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion .
 The communication of the critical audit matter does not alter in any way our opinion on the consolidated financial statements, taken as a whole, and we are not providing a separate opinion . The Company is subject to claims, lawsuits, regulatory and government inquiries and investigations, other proceedings, and orders involving competition, intellectual property, data privacy and security, tax and related compliance, labor and employment .
 In our opinion, Alphabet Inc. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2024, based on the criteria established in Internal Control—Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (2013 framework) We have served as the Company's auditor since 1999 .
 Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists . We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion . We are a public accounting firm registered with the PCAOB and are required to be independent with respect to the Company in accordance with the U.S. federal securities laws .
 Internal control over financial reporting includes policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company . Internal control may not prevent or detect misstatements. accounting principles . Internal controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate .
 The Alphabet Inc. made the following statement of non-GAGA results for the year ended December 31, 2018 . The Company paid $1.6 billion in cash and interest in the company's net assets . The company paid $7,493 in cash, including $2.5 billion in non-taxes and $1 billion in taxes . The total value of the company’s operating and non-operating lease assets is $17,180 .
 The company's basic net income per share (Note 12) is $4.59-$5.84-$8.13 per share . The Company's net income is $59,972-$73,795 ($100,118) The Company paid $207,994-$223,101 costs and expenses previously gathered in compound expenses and other comprehensive income (loss)
 Stockholders’ share price as of December 31, 2021, $1.60 per share and $1,800 per share declared . The company's net balance as of Dec. 31, 2022, $12,849 - $12,460 - 2023, €1,500 -  $1,600 per share . The Company’s net balance is $1 million .
 The Alphabet Inc. made the following statement of statements of operations and expenditures . The Company paid $245,084 in cash and $100,118 in cash, expenses and other expenses . The company paid $9,837 in cash in the year ended December 31, 2018 . The amount of investments received and receiptions increased to $9,795,79572 .
 Google was incorporated in California in September 1998 and re-incorporated in the State of Delaware in August 2003 . In 2015, we implemented a holding company reorganization, and as a result, Alphabet Inc. ("Alphabet") became the successor issuer to Google . The consolidated financial statements of Alphabet include the accounts of Alphabet and entities consolidated under the variable interest and voting models .
 Actual results could differ from these estimates due to uncertainties . Revenues are recognized when control of the promised goods or services is transferred to our customers . Sales and other similar taxes are excluded from revenues . We base our estimates on assumptions, both historical and forward looking, that are believed to be reasonable . We generate advertising revenues primarily by delivering advertising on Google Search .
 For ads placed on Google Network properties, we evaluate whether we are the principal (i.e., report revenues on a gross basis) or agent . We report revenues from Google Play sales of apps and in-app purchases on a net basis . We recognize revenues when the ad is displayed, or a user views the ad . Google Subscriptions, Platforms, and Devices revenues consist of revenues from subscription services .
 Our cloud services are generally provided on either a consumption or subscription basis . Revenues related to cloud services provided on a consumption basis are recognized when the customer utilizes the services, based on the quantity of services consumed . Certain customers receive cash-based incentives or credits, which are accounted for as variable consideration . We believe there will not be significant changes to our estimates of variable consideration related to customer incentives and credits .
 Costs of revenues consists of TAC and other costs of revenues . Costs are recorded within sales and marketing expenses . Google Network partners primarily for ads displayed on their properties . Software development costs include costs to develop software products or the software component of products to be sold, leased, or marketed to external users, before technological feasibility is reached .
 Software development costs also include costs to develop software to be used solely to meet internal needs and cloud-based applications used to deliver our services . We capitalize development costs related to these software applications once the preliminary project stage is complete and it is probable that the project will be completed and the software will be used to perform the function intended .
 The fair value of awards granted by Other Bet companies is based on the equity valuation of the respective Other Bet company . For the years ended  December 31, 2022, 2023, and 2024, advertising and promotional expenses totaled approximately $9.2.2-8.7-2-7.2 billion . Performance fees are recorded as a component of OI&E .
 These models project future cash flows and discount the future amounts to a present value using market-based observable inputs including interest rate curves, foreign exchange rates, and credit ratings . The fair value hierarchy requires an entity to maximize the use of observable inputs when measuring fair value . We manage our credit risk exposure through timely assessment of our counterparty creditworthiness, credit limits, and use of collateral .
 We generally do not require collateral from our customers . Accounts receivable are typically unsecured and are derived from revenues earned from customers . We may sell these debt securities prior to their effective maturities . We carry these securities at fair value, and report the unrealized gains and losses, net of taxes, as a component of stockholders’ equity .
 For certain marketable debt securities we have elected the fair value option, for which changes in fair value are recorded in OI&E . We determine any realized gains and losses on the sale of marketable . debt securities on a specific identification method . We account for non-marketable equity securities through which we exercise significant influence but do not have control over the investee under the equity method .
 Accounts receivable includes amounts for services performed in advance of the right to invoice the customer . The term between invoicing and when payment is due is not significant . We assess collectibility by reviewing accounts receivable on a collective basis where similar characteristics exist and on an individual basis . We also consider customer-specific information, current market conditions, and reasonable and supportable forecasts of future economic conditions .
 We periodically review our debt and non-marketable equity securities for impairment . Credit loss is recorded as a charge to OI&E, not to exceed the amount of the unrealized loss . Unrealized losses other than the credit loss are recognized in AOCI . If we have an intent to sell, or if it is more likely than not that we will be required to sell a debt security before recovery of its amortized cost basis .
 Alphabet Inc. is the primary beneficiary of a VIE when we have the power to direct activities that most significantly affect the economic performance of the VIE and have the obligation to absorb the majority of their losses or benefits . In inventory, inventory consists primarily of finished goods and is stated at the lower of cost and net realizable value .
 Goodwill impairments were referred to reporting units based on the expected benefit from the business combination . Depreciate data center and office buildings over periods of  seven-to-40 years . Leases generally contain lease and non-lease components . Payments under our lease arrangements are primarily fixed . Land is not depreciated .
 Lease assets and liabilities are recognized at the present value of the future lease payments at the lease commencement date . The interest rate used to determine present value is our incremental borrowing rate . The current portion of our operating lease liabilities is included in accrued expenses and other current liabilities . Finance lease assets are included in property and equipment, net .
 The evaluation is performed when events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying amount may not be recoverable . We measure recoverability of these assets by comparing the carrying amounts to the future undiscounted cash flows that the assets or the asset group are expected to generate . The impairment recognized is measured as the amount by which the carrying value exceeds its fair value .
 We include the results of operations of the businesses that we acquire as of the acquisition date . We record translation gains and losses in AOCI as a component of stockholders’ equity . The excess of the purchase price over the fair values of identifiable assets and liabilities is recorded as goodwill . We recognize interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits as a part of the income tax provision .
 In November 2024, the FASB issued ASU 2024-03 "Income Statement: Reporting Comprehensive Income-Expense Disaggregation Disclosures (Subtopic 220-40)" The standard can be applied either prospectively or retrospectively . We will adopt the standard in our 2025 annual period and are currently assessing the effect that the updated standard will have on financial statement disclosures .
 The following table presents revenues disaggregated by geography, based on the addresses of our customers (in millions): Europe, Middle East, Asia-Pacific (APAC) and Canada and Latin America (Other Americas) The revenue backlog represents commitments in customer contracts for future services that have not yet been recognized as revenue .
 The revenue backlog includes related deferred revenue currently recorded as well as amounts that will be invoiced in future periods . The estimated revenue backlog and timing of revenue recognition for these commitments is largely driven by our ability to deliver in accordance with relevant contract terms and when our customers utilize services . Deferred revenues primarily relate to Google Cloud and Google subscriptions, platforms, and devices .
 The fair value option was elected for these securities to align with the unrealized gains and losses from related derivative contracts . The carrying value of the $65.65. lion as of . December 31, 2023 is included within . other non current assets. The carrying value of marketable equity securities is not readily determined .
 The carrying value of our non-marketable equity securities is adjusted to fair value upon observable transactions for identical or similar investments of the same issuer or impairment . Valuable securities that have been remeasured at fair value are classified within Level 2 or Level 3 in the fair value hierarchy . The following tables present fair values and gross unrealized losses recorded to AOCI, aggregated by investment category and length of time that individual securities have been in a continuous loss position .

 In the table above, realized net gain (loss) on equity securities sold during the period reflects the difference between the sale proceeds and the carrying value of the equity securities at the beginning of the period or the purchase date, if later . Cumulative net gains (losses) are calculated as the difference . Equity securities accounted for under the equity method had a carrying value  of approximately $1.7.7 billion and $2.2 billion .
 Alphabet Inc. uses derivative instruments to manage risks relating to our ongoing business operations . The primary risk managed is foreign exchange risk . We use foreign currency contracts to reduce the risk that our cash flows, earnings, and investment in foreign subsidiaries will be adversely affected by foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations . The accounting treatment for derivatives is based on the intended use and hedge designation .
 Cash flow hedge amounts included in the assessment of hedge effectiveness are deferred in AOCI and subsequently reclassified to revenue when the hedged item is recognized in earnings . These contracts have maturities of  24 months or less . We exclude forward points and time value from hedge effectiveness and amortize them on a straight-line basis over the life of the hedging instrument in revenues .
 Alphabet Inc. nter into foreign currency forward and option contracts that are not designated as hedging instruments to hedge intercompany transactions . Gains and losses arising from other derivatives are primarily reflected within the ‘other’ component of OI&E . The gross notional amounts of outstanding derivative instruments were as follows (in millions): As of December 31, 2023 and 2024 .
 The gains (losses) on derivatives in cash flow hedging and net investment hedging relationships recognized in other comprehensive income (OCI) are summarized below (in millions) Derivative assets are recorded as other current and non-current assets in the Consolidated Balance Sheets . Derivatives not designated as hedging instruments are recorded  as accrued expenses and other liabilities .
 The gross amounts of derivative instruments subject to master netting arrangements with various counterparties were as follows (in millions): Gross Amounts Not Offset in the Consolidated Balance Sheets, but Have Legal Rights to Offset . Cash and non-cash collateral pledged related to derivative instruments under our collateral security arrangements are included in other current assets .
 The balances as of December 31, 2023 and 2024 were related to derivatives allowed to be net settled in accordance with our master netting agreements .  As of December 31, 2024, we have entered into leases that have not yet commenced with short-term and long-term future lease payments of $773.773 million and $6.5 billion, respectively, that are not yet recorded on our Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows as repayments of debt . Future lease payments will commence between 2025 and 2028 with non-cancelable lease terms .
 The results of operations and financial position of these VIEs are included in our consolidated financial statements . Waymo, a fully autonomous driving technology company and a consolidated VIE, received $5.6.6-billion in funding during the year ended December 31, 2024 . The majority of that funding was funded by Alphabet .
 The results of operations and financial position of these VIEs are not included in our consolidated financial statements . We account for these investments primarily as non-marketable equity securities or equity method investments . We have a debt financing program of up to $10.0 billion through the issuance of commercial paper . Net proceeds from this program are used for general corporate purposes .
 The notes in the table above are fixed-rate senior unsecured obligations and rank equally with each other . We may redeem the notes at any time in whole or in part at specified redemption prices . The effective interest rates are based on proceeds received with interest payable semi-annually . The total estimated fair value of the outstanding notes was approximately $10.3 billion and  $9.0 billion as of December 31, 2023 and  December 31, 2024 .
 The allowance for credit losses on accounts receivable was $771.771 million and $879 million as of December 31, 2023 and 2024 . The amounts related to the EC fines, including any under appeal, are included in accrued expenses and other current liabilities on our Consolidated Balance Sheets . In the third quarter of 2024 we made a cash payment of $3.0 billion for the 2017 EC shopping fine .
 The effects on net income of amounts reclassified from AOCI were as follows (in millions):    The effects of the reclassifications were  reclassed as to account payments reclassified from accounts to accounts payable . The amount reclassified was included in accounts payable accounts payable and accounts payable.
 In August 2024, we entered into a license agreement with Character pursuant to which we obtained a non-exclusive license to its then current large  large   large business . In accordance with the accounting requirements under Accounting Standards Codification Topic 805, for the year ended December 31, 2024,  we recorded $.7.7 billion of goodwill and $.413. million of intangible assets resulting from a transaction with character.ai (“Character”)
 Goodwill was recorded in Google Services and Google Cloud and is deductible for tax purposes . We paid Character $2.7.7 billion in cash and canceled our convertible instruments . We also hired certain employees of Character. language model technology . Goodwill is recorded in . Google Services . Google Cloud . Google also indemnify certain parties, including advertisers, Google .
 As of December 31, 2024, we did not have any material indemnification claims that were probable or reasonably possible . We record a liability when we believe that it is probable that a loss has been incurred, and the amount can be reasonably estimated . We evaluate developments in our legal matters that could affect the amount of liability that has been previously accrued .
 The outcomes of outstanding legal matters are inherently unpredictable and subject to significant uncertainties, and could, either individually or in aggregate, have a material adverse effect . We are subject to formal and informal inquiries and investigations as well as litigation on various competition matters by regulatory authorities and private parties in the U.S., Europe, and other jurisdictions globally .
 In March 2019, the EC announced its decision that certain provisions in Google's agreements with AdSense for Search partners infringed European antitrust laws . The EC has appealed the General Court's decision with the European Court of Justice . The DOJ and a number of state Attorneys General filed a lawsuit alleging that Google violated U.S. antitrust laws relating to Search and Search advertising .
 The DOJ, along with a number of state Attorneys General, filed a lawsuit alleging that Google violated U.S. antitrust laws as well as state deceptive trade laws relating to its advertising technology . A California jury delivered a verdict in Epic Games v. Google that Google vio. on into Search distribution practices. The EC issued a Statement of Objections in June 2023, informing Google of its preliminary view that Google . Google reached a settlement in principle with 50 state . Attorneys general and three territories . Final approval of the settlement remains pending before the court .
 Epic did not seek monetary damages in the case . The presiding judge issued a remedies decision in October 2024, ordering a variety of alterations to our business models and operations and contractual agreements for Android and Google Play . We are appealing the verdict and the trial court judge temporarily paused the implementation of the remedies while the Court of Appeals considers our request to pause implementation .
 We have had patent, copyright, trade secret, and trademark infringement lawsuits filed against us claiming that certain of our products, services, and technologies infringe others' intellectual property rights . Adverse results in these lawsuits may include awards of substantial monetary damages, costly royalty or licensing agreements, or orders preventing us from offering certain features, functionalities, products, or services .
 We do not expect these ongoing legal matters will have a material adverse effect . We are under audit by various domestic and foreign tax authorities with regards to non-income tax matters . Non-income taxes may result from examinations by, or any negotiated agreements with, these tax authorities when a loss is probable and reasonably estimable. If we determine that a loss or range of loss can be estimated, we disclose the reasonably possible loss .
 The final outcome may be materially different from our expectations . The rights of the holders of each class of our common and capital stock are identical, except with respect to voting rights . Class A and Class B common stock may be converted at the option of the stockholder and automatically convert upon sale or transfer to Class A common stock .
 The repurchase program does not have an expiration date . The company intends to pay quarterly cash dividends in the future, subject to review and approval by the company’s Board of Directors in its sole discretion . The repurchases are executed from time to time subject to general business and market conditions and other investment opportunities, through open market purchases or privately negotiated transactions .
 In accordance with our certificate of incorporation, the rights, including the liquidation and dividend rights, of the holders of our Class A, Class B, and Class C stock are identical, except with respect to voting rights . Delaware law prevents Board of Directors from declaring or paying unequal per share dividends on our Class A, . Class B stock does not assume the conversion of those shares .
 The company's net income per share is based on a basic net income of $4.56 per share . The company paid $27,518 per share in cash and interest in shares . The Company paid $39.5 per share for shares outstanding . The net income was $31,360 per share, with the net value of $1.9 per share held at the company's expense of $3.2 per share.
 Not applicable for consolidated net income per share . Net income from conversion of Class B to Class A shares is not applicable for consolidated net income . Average number of shares used in basic computation: 5,922.722.822.2.5,831.6,799.2,923.2 .
 The Alphabet Amended and Restated 2021 Stock Plan and Other Bets stock-based plans may be granted . An RSU award is an agreement to issue shares of our Class C stock at the time the award vests . As of December 31, 2024, there were  633.33 million shares of Class C . stock reserved for future issuance under the Alphabet 2021 Stock . Plan .
 The weighted-average grant-date fair value of RSUs granted during the years ended December 31, 2022, 2023, and 2024 was $127.22.22/2023 . Total fair value for unvested RSUs, as of their respective vesting dates, was $23.9 billion, $26.6.6 billion, and $.3 billion, respectively . As of December 31, 2024, there was $34.8 billion of unrecognized compensation cost related to unvesting RSUs . This amount is expected to be recognized over a weighted average period of 2.5 years .
 As of December 31, the IRS issued a rule change allowing taxpayers to temporarily apply the regulations in effect prior to 2022 related to U.S. federal foreign tax credits as well as a separate rule change with guidance on the capitalization and amortization of R&D expenses . A cumulative one-time adjustment for these tax rule changes was recorded in 2023 .
 As of December 31, 2024, our federal, state, and foreign net operating loss carryforwards for income tax purposes were approximately $8.4 billion, $19.4 billion, and $2.5 billion respectively . If not utilized, the majority of the federal tax credit and state tax credit is not likely to be realized . We believe the Federal R&D credit will begin to expire in 2037 and the California R.D credit can be carried over indefinitely .
 The total amount of gross unrecognized tax benefits was $7.1.1 billion, $9.4.4 billion, and $12.6 billion as of December 31, 2022, 2023, and 2024 . We are subject to income taxes in the U.S. and foreign jurisdictions . Significant judgment is required in evaluating our uncertain tax positions .
 The major tax jurisdictions are the U.S. federal and Ireland . The IRS is currently examining our 2016 through 2021 tax returns . The tax years 2016 through 2023 remain subject to examination by the appropriate governmental agencies for Irish tax purposes . If any issues addressed in our tax audits are resolved in a manner not consistent with management's expectations, we could be required to adjust our provision for income taxes .
 The timing of resolution, settlement, and closure of audits is not certain, we do not believe it is reasonably possible that our unrecognized tax benefits from certain U.S. tax benefits will materially change in the next 12 months .  There have been no changes in our internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the quarter ended December 31, 2024 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, the company's internal control of financial reporting .  There were no "non-Rule 10b5-1 trading arrangements" (as defined in Item 408 of Regulation S-K of the Exchange Act) adopted, modified, or terminated during the quarter ended December 31, 2024 by our directors and Section 16 officers . The trading and actual sale transactions made pursuant to such trading arrangements will be disclosed publicly in Section 16 filings with the SEC .
 The Board of Directors of Alphabet approved the accrual of dividend equivalent units to current and future holders of all unvested stock units in connection with any regular cash dividend that may be declared by the board of directors . As stock units are not outsized shares of stock and thus would not otherwise be entitled to participate in any dividends, the crediting of dividend  units is intended to preserve the equity-based incentives intended by the company when the stock units were granted .
 We have adopted insider trading policies governing the purchase, sale, and other dispositions of securities of Alphabet by directors, officers, and employees . Our insider trading policy states, among other things, that our directors and officers are prohibited from trading in such securities while in possession of material, nonpublic information .
